column6: content

Christian Owens

Major software products have moved to a subscription business model in the last couple of years - some successfully, some attracting considerable customer backlash. We've seen many indie Mac developers considering it but unsure how to do it, from figuring out and testing the best pricing and billing models to avoiding backlash to managing the technical aspects of running both one-off customers and recurring subscriptions in parallel. To help developers considering that approach, I propose a fireside chat where I would moderate a discussion with several leaders of awesome Mac products who have both strong opinions, and real life experience in that tricky move. Some of them our customers, some of them friends of us - all of them with really interesting, and often different views on the topic. We are currently discussing WWDC presence with them, so here's an indicative list of the key developers with whom I'd run the session (3-4 of them will join): - Opposed to subscriptions: RogueAmoeba or Panic - Enthusiastic on subscriptions: Framer, Ulysses or Tower - Offering a 3rd, in-between approach: Sketch, Smile Software or Setapp The session will focus on practical examples of what went well and what went horribly wrong, to make it very actionable for the audience - no fluff, sales pitch or vague ideas, just concrete learnings, both from a technical and a business standpoints.

Daniel Devesa Derksen-Staats

It is the moment you have been working so hard for. You press the ‘Submit’ button. Your app is now on its way to the App Store. In just a few days, your app is going to be available globally. But… is it really? Any developer of an app with an aim of reaching a global audience needs to localise the app (most of us do that), but also to make it accessible! In this talk we will try to provide a few techniques for improving those two areas of your apps from the points of view of the code, the use of tools we have available and the users’ expected experience. A series of examples will be presented, showing how some of your users may perceive your app when localisation and accessibility are not correctly implemented or not implemented at all. You would freak out if the ‘Back’ button was on the right side of the navigation bar, but that is what users that speak right-to-left written languages expect. If a modal view was presented without a ‘Close/Done’ button, you would consider it a bug, but it may exactly be what you are giving to blind users. Smartphones, apps and the whole Apple ecosystem has helped us develop much more inclusive apps that anyone can use. But we can do better by building apps for everyone.

Dan Hixon

We have all heard and been inspired by success stories. Tales of success are great! From Apollo XI to Falcon Heavy, the original Macintosh to the iPhone– it’s so satisfying when the odds seem against us and yet we prevail. The problem with success stories is that they are only told by the people who have succeeded. This is called survivorship bias. [https://www.xkcd.com/1827/] “Never stop buying lottery tickets…” I’ve been self-employed for two and a half years trying to make a living in the App Store. My goal is to be earning enough money to provide for my family. I’m not there yet but I have made money. I have also checked items off my bucket list because l've been trying to achieve this goal. I want to share my story precisely because it isn’t a bona-fide success story yet. I hope I can inspire you with it–I hope my talk will help you try something you’ve been wanting to try. -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- I will tell stories of my business. My business partner and I travel to remote and beautiful places to capture aerial videos for our relaxation and meditation app. To make an omelet you must break eggs; We’ve crashed about $10k worth of quadcopters. I'll tell 4 drone crash stories - how they shaped our business and attitudes about failure. I'll tell the story of us attending WWDC and Alt-Conf last year while sleeping in our car. I’ll talk about our marketing efforts, pricing strategies, etc. The difficulty we have, as artists, to promote ourselves and our product. The necessity of living on a tight budget has been a mother of invention for me. Resulting in new skills, personality traits, and possibilities.

column1: How to train your own model for CoreML
column6:
Reza Shirazian

The talk will be a quicker version of this article I wrote back in July https://reza.codes/2017-07-29/how-to-train-your-own-dataset-for-coreml/

column1: 9 Lessons Learned from Scaling a New App Business to $1M Recurring Revenue in 6 Months
column6:
Yaroslav Stepanenko

To go from a standing start to over $1 million in 6 months is, as the majority in the app development community would agree, a positive sign that we’re offering an app service that customers around the world want. Achieving this sort of growth in a relatively short period of time - only 6 months - is challenging. We have learned A LOT from this journey, so we wanted to share with you 9 of the most valuable lessons: Lesson 1: Make a Product Launch EXCLUSIVE Lesson 2: Work with Innovators and Early Adopters First, every time. No exceptions Lesson 3: Build a community before aiming for revenue Lesson 4: Winning new customers is only half the battle Lesson 5: Not all metrics carry the same importance Lesson 6: Create a referral program Lesson 7: Decide when to go global Lesson 8: Segment packages around customer needs Lesson 9: Plan and deploy resources and teams effectively. Increase collaborative opportunities

column1: Being technical on how to clean tech debt
column6:
Fabio Cerdeiral

Quick talk on how to tackle technical debt in your team. Here I'd reference several articles I've had on how to classify your tech debt and prioritize it accordingly. Things you should tackle as soon as possible to avoid spreading if it's easily dependent and buried deep inside the system and some other things you should just set as lower priority because it's contained and the impact on the user experience is minimal.

Ben Easton

There are thousands of languages in the world and yet we can easily get lost in just creating for an English audience. Based on my experience adding multiple languages to the Coffee Meets Bagel iOS app I will discuss some of the challenges in creating a localizable app. The following will be included: • How NSLocalizedString works • Why string concatenation is so deadly • String dictionary files • How to deal with plurals and genders. • General things to avoid and keep in mind when designing for internationalization.

column1: Creating macOS Build Infrastructure in the Cloud with MacStadium
column6:
Shawn Lankton

iOS and macOS app development can be challenging since builds have to run on Genuine Apple Mac infrastructure. More companies than you might think end up with Mac minis piled up in a closet, but they quickly run into challenges with security and scalability. In this session, learn how MacStadium deploys Mac hardware, SAN storage, and virtualization technology to create robust, scalable clouds perfect for iOS/macOS development, testing, and continuous integration.

column1: I hate public speaking. So why do I keep doing it?
column6:
Francisco Diaz

Last year, after a talk I gave in my hometown someone asked me ""Why do you give talks?"" I couldn't answer honestly. The first reaction I get when I hear public speaking is panic. Every time I need to jump on stage I feel that cold sweat running down the back of my neck. Why do I keep doing it if it’s so uncomfortable? In this talk, I’ll not only try to answer that question but also tackle some of the most common misunderstandings surrounding tech talks. Is the speaker the most technically capable? Do they have a special knowledge about the topic they’re discussing? The best professionals I’ve worked with in my career have been great communicators. As with any skill, this needs to be trained. I'll argue that public speaking is a great way to improve our communication skills and to get out of our comfort zone.

Erwin Mazariegos

I am currently building a client app with an AR mode. This is my first production app using SceneKit, and I am learning a lot. I also find it a bit frustrating, but am figuring out various tricks to help with debugging, and I am settling in on some practices that help the development process. I am working with basic primitive shapes: rectangles, cylinders, spheres, extruded text, and spotlights, directly in code and using the SceneKit Editor. I am animating objects, morphing shapes, and playing video (including in a Harry-Potter-esque short loop preview).

Speaker

TBD

Alexis Gallagher

ARKit has given iOS devices magical new powers but even this magic has limits — limits based on hardware requirements and on API precision. This session will describe how, at the startup where I work in SF, we use a variety of familiar iOS frameworks, as well as some of our own machine learning models, in order to build an augmented reality experience that goes beyond ARKit. Our app provides an AR view of the user wearing custom glasses -- but without using an iPhone X, and of a higher precision than what the iPhone X provides. If you're wondering what you can do with ARKit out of the box, and what it takes to build powerful experiences without it, come to this talk.

column1: How to not fail on the App Store
column6:
Ariel Michaeli

Making a great app is hard, but making a successful app is even harder if you only think about the technical. As the founder of an app analytics company I've learned many lessons about building app companies, which I will share in this fun and energetic talk.

column1: Bootstrapping the Machine Learning Training Process
column6:
Meghan Kane

When is it valuable to consider using machine learning to help solve your iOS app’s problems? We will go through criteria to evaluate that, practical use cases of incorporating ML models on device, and how to bootstrap the training process for creating machine learning models that will run on device (iOS). You may think that lots of data, compute power, time, and expertise are necessary to train custom models; however, this is not the case! Using techniques such as transfer learning and taking inspiration from the plentiful resources from industry and academia, you can get started doing this now. In this talk, we will go through training custom machine learning models using Tensor Flow across different domains (image classification, audio classification, & more). And, yes, we will move beyond the dog / cat classifier. Additionally, we will cover the state of ML for iOS: what has been available since iOS 11 (Core ML, Vision, etc), announcements from WWDC 2018, and Swift for Tensor Flow.

column1: FullStack Swift from Prototype to Production in 3 Months - the Ask Mercedes Story
column6:
Chris Bailey

Swift on the server arrived with the promise the to enable Swift developers to become ""Fullstack"", building end-to-end Swift applications. It also promised to enable higher levels of productivity through the reused of code, as well as greater safety and less bugs through the reuse of the data types. Two years on, has Swift on the server delivered on that promise? In this session, Marco Gloria from Mercedes Benz will describe how his team built the Ask Mercedes application, which went from prototype to production using Kitura in just three months, describing both the challenges and successes he had. Additionally, Chris Bailey from the Kitura team will describe how the server side Swift ecosystem is continuing to advance, and what new capabilities are arriving to make it even easier to build production applications.

column1: Storming the Castle: Why Do Your Users Hate You And What Can You Do About It?
column6:
Shaun Lewis

This is a fast-moving, but entertaining talk that has some horror stories to drive home the point that users shouldn't have to use the App Store review text box or a random support email as the only places they can contact you. I show how O'Reilly Media uses in-app feedback within the app to listen to users and provide a pressure relief valve for their frustrations. I also talk about why it's important for developers to talk directly to customers and how we have empowered our mobile devs to engage with their users and to listen to their feedback in a way that helps drive product development.

Greg Heo

Having shared mutable state is often the default for our applications: a view with a lot of properties that gets passed around, or an app delegate accessible from everywhere that holds state. Shared mutable state can be the source of many headaches — it makes it difficult to trace through your programs, and hard to reason about concurrency. In this session, we'll look at examples of *why* this is the case and two ways of *how* to fix it: 1) use shared but immutable state; or 2) mutable but unshared state. Between shared and mutable, you should pick just one and by the end of this talk you'll know how to make that choice.

column1: A Tour of the Photo Capture Pipeline
column6:
Benjamin Sandofsky

Whether you're diving into computer vision or building a photo-filter app, it's important to understand the photo capture pipeline. We'll explain debayering, chroma-subsampling, gamma compression, and more. If you've reached the limits of high level APIs and now you're ready to get your hands dirty, this talk is for you.

Jon Shier

Since its first release in 2015, Alamofire has become one of the most popular Swift frameworks. In the three years since that 1.0.0 release, it has gained more and more features, and the internal complexity to go along with them. For version 5, however, we realized it was time to rewrite the core of the library to enable further growth, new features, and greater scalability. In this presentation I will explore the reasoning behind this risky decision and how we were able to use our existing test suite to replace the core of the framework while largely maintaining compatibility for existing Alamofire users.

Paul Hudson

What better way to explore all the new goodies from Apple than with live coding demonstrations of the most important new features?

Jeroen Zonneveld

CloudKit is introduced in 2014. It's a cloud solution from Apple to easily save and store data to the iCloud database of your app user. This talk will give an introduction on how to setup CloudKit for your app, what the benefits are and how developers can query and store data to iCloud using CloudKit. CloudKit is available since iOS 8.0+, macOS 10.10+, tvOS 9.0+ and watchOS 3.0+.
Speaker

Nilofer Rajpurkar

Keeping up with speedy development is difficult, especially when your process is manual. Automate your life and see how a continuous everything approach can speed up your process and help you provide your users with the most value. Worried about the time and pain in setting this up? Let's journey through painlessly setting up a continuous pipeline for your iOS apps.

column1: Using data to better understand your users
column6:
Bo-ying Fu

You've shipped an app, and the reviews are coming in. People generally seem to like your app but now what? How do you make decisions on what to do next? Are your users using the features as intended? What is success? Telemetry is the way to get broad answers s without needing to interview all of your users. It’s important to know the difference between what you think your user are doing vs what they are actually doing. Ask questions and answer with real data to drive effective decisions in your development process.

Minh Nguyen

The Mapbox Maps SDK for iOS powers high-performance maps based on open data, with an elegant API in Objective-C and Swift. The recent v4.0 release features a renewed emphasis on customizability: you can alter every aspect of the map’s appearance using NSExpression and NSPredicate. We heavily extended NSExpression’s set of first-class functions with a raft of new “aftermarket” functions for common map-related operations. This lightning talk explains the technical details of the Mapbox Maps SDK’s extensions, the API design considerations that led us to this approach, and some of the practical use cases for expressions in maps.

column1: Building Apps with Swift - from Simple to Solution
column6:
Chris Bailey

Over the course of a short 10 minutes, we will take you on a journey, one in which a simple app grows up. From an early self-contained MVP app, we'll quickly start to enhance it with additional capabilities to add authentication and multi-device support, social sharing, security and even cognitive and machine learning capabilities. What's more, you'll see how all of this can be done using only Swift.

column1: How to prototype and test user experiences quickly
column6:
Joe Mellin

Look at how to learn what to build as quickly as possible. See how you can leverage different tools from paper prototyping, to click through mockups, leverage usertesting.com and receive qualitative feedback to shape your decision making and drive development process to create better user experiences.

column1: Machine Learning on iOS: Integrating IBM Watson with Core ML
column6:
Tom Markiewicz

Apple recently announced a partnership with IBM to integrate Core ML with Watson, allowing visual recognition to run locally on iOS devices. The ability to use machine learning while offline opens up a wide range of applications and use cases. Geared toward beginners (both in Swift and machine learning), this session will focus on providing an overview of machine learning and Core ML, how to implement IBM Watson with Core ML, and techniques for continuous learning and model training. Additionally, we’ll cover the benefits of using machine learning locally and what’s in store for the future.

Timirah James

At just four years old, Swift is quickly becoming even more popular than it’s thirty-three year old predecessor, Objective-C. Experience in Swift is becoming more desirable and in demand in the iOS force as companies both old and new transition and migrate their code for the new Swift takeover. In this talk, I’ll be giving an “Objective-C OG” style intro to the Swift language (for those who have experience in the Obj-C language). Some of the things we’ll be covering in this talk will include: Swift vs. Objective-C syntax comparison The evolution of Swift The future of Swift The future of Objective-C By the end of this talk, attendees will have gained a basic understanding of the concept of the Swift language in comparison to Objective-C, as well as the knowledge and resources to continue exploring and building their skills in Swift.

column1: Mac Developer Survey Results by MacPaw: app distribution channels, challenges developers face and the solutions they find, and much more.
column6:
Yaroslav Stepanenko

700+ developers responded to an annual survey and shared their thoughts on the Mac App Store and the state of Mac app development. Come and see what the market is now compared to a year ago, and what’s coming. Here is last year’s report: https://setapp.com/mac-market-survey-2017, that was announced at AltConf 2017 (https://academy.realm.io/posts/altconf-2017-yaroslav-stepanenko-macpaw-mac-developers-survey-results/) This year it will be once again exclusively announced at AltConf 2018.

column1: The Secret Life of a Digital Nomad: The New Normal
column6:
Natasha Murashev

I've been a digital nomad for three years now. Although it started out bumpy, it is now my new normal. Learn how choosing a digital nomad lifestyle will change your life in ways you haven't imagined, including how you handle money, how you make friends, and the unforeseen choices you get to make every single day.

column1: Building An App Company - It's More Than Code
column6:
Michael Sacks

This talk is designed for the engineer who wants to try entrepreneurship. I believe that there are many iOS devs who have worked for other people their whole careers, but want to try to go at it on their own. My talk is designed to teach iOS developers about the differences and similarities between iOS development and entrepreneurship. I'd like to help iOS devs make their risk taking more calculated.

column1: Improving user experience with Apple Pencil
column6:
Douglas Hill

Apple Pencil unlocks a different way to interact with iPad, which can be both efficient and comfortable. I’ve implemented enhanced support for Apple Pencil in our product and would like to share what I learned. This would be most beneficial to anyone making an iPad app that supports drawing. However I think Apple Pencil could enhance other kinds of apps too, and the topic is generally interesting. The talk would cover both design and implementation. I would discuss: • The benefits of Apple Pencil for users and what features it works well for. • How to detect the Pencil and distinguish it from finger touches. • How to increase realism and responsiveness using coalesced and predicted touches. • Performance. While this is highly dependent on your codebase, I can share some general tips for using Instruments to identify bottlenecks and some possible ways to make your code faster.

Kate Rotondo

Core Data is a robust iOS persistence solution. So why does it strike fear in the heart of new developers? Together, let's demystify the components of the Core Data stack: the data model, one or more managed object contexts, the persistent store coordinator, and the persistent container. We’ll bring each class to life, exploring its unique role, and how all of the classes work together as a system to save and load data on the device. Then we’ll peek through the doors that open once you understand these basics, including updating your UI in response to data changes, migrating data versions, and backgrounding long data tasks. You’ll leave with a really clear mental model of what Core Data offers, and the confidence to add it to your projects.

Jen Person

Firebase is best known for its Realtime Database offering, but there’s so much more to it! It’s a whole suite of tools to help you build your app and grow your user base on mobile. Come learn about Firebase offerings that make app development quick and scalable. See some of the features of Firebase like MLKit, Cloud Firestore, Cloud Storage, Dynamic Links, and Auth. If you’re already familiar with Firebase, this is for you, too! We’re going to dive into some code and talk practices for managing asynchronous data from Firebase.

column1: Scalable iOS Applications with Serverless and Kubernetes
column6:
Jennie Oliver & Andy Trice

Learn about popular application development trends that companies are following to disrupt their industries. We'll walk through how to build a scalable iOS app that could run on Serverless or Kubernetes using DevOps best practices.

column1: The importance of Privacy in iOS
column6:
Manuel Carrasco-Molina

A lot of time Privacy of my data as a user is not a priority for Developers. Wether it's my calendar, my contacts, my location, I want as a user to be able to use an app without all of those attacks in my privacy. I want to summarise everything an iOS developer should do to ensure the most critical user can still use my app in some regards, and not just say "I need all your information" like on other platforms. This is the beauty of iOS, being able to fine grained (although not enough) so let's do this all together, as a beautiful community concerned by Privacy.

column1: Millions of customers. Billions of dollars. Real-world iOS Architecture at Scale.
column6:
Parveen Kaler

The architecture for the Item Page in Walmart's iOS App has evolved from 50,000 lines of Objective-C sitting on top of a REST API implemented as a UITableView to much less Swift code sitting on top of a GraphQL API implemented as a UICollectionView. We will talk about the evolutionary process. We will talk about lessons learned over the years. The pros/cons of different architecture decisions.

Robert Spivack

HomeKit is Apple's official foray into Smart Home automation systems. HomeKit brings modern user interface and user experience paradigms to the stodgy world of traditional overpriced and proprietary control solutions costing up to $100,000 or more. While off to a good start, HomeKit has many limitations which has made it an easy target of ridicule by old school professional systems integrators. A few innovative integrators are swimming upstream selling and installing systems based on HomeKit but face many obstacles trying to match the capability of existing competitors.  This talk by a systems integrator “in the trenches” will present a summary of the current limitations encountered with HomeKit highlighting the opportunities for indie developers to help bridge the gap. The focus is on presenting product ideas for embracing and extending HomeKit with profitable complementary software apps and services to solve these limitations. Home automation is a vertical market that is currently undergoing explosive growth and Apple HomeKit has the potential to become a dominant solution. Developers with the right skills and interest can find interesting product and revenue opportunities that most are overlooking. The market demand is there, the products are not (yet).

column1: Going Open Source: Advantages and Lessons Learned
column6:
Matheus Cardoso

What does Open Source mean for iOS developers today? What are the ""dos and don'ts"" of maintaining an Open Source project? How does it fit in a viable business model and is there an actual advantage? In this talk I'll share my experience maintaining the iOS version of Rocket.Chat - an Open Source communication platform with daily contributions from all around the globe.

Jeff Kelley

Have you ever had a bug that dealt with dates and times? Dealing with time zones, Daylight Saving Time, and the like can make the hair on the back of even the most experienced developer's neck stand up. We all know how to tell time and how calendars work, and yet these bugs are terrifying. Why? Using Swift as a lens to walk through common problems, we’ll explore writing date and time code that’s correct and easy to understand. You’ll leave with an approach to solving calendrical calculations without fear, new tools for handling these problems in your code, and a huge appreciation for the people behind the libraries that make this possible.

James Dempsey

Join James Dempsey for his fifth annual Week In Review, a lighthearted look back at the announcements of WWDC 2018. Close out AltConf in style with a session that combines easy-going humor, music, and perspective from a fifteen year Apple veteran gone indie. And as usual, there will be a bit involving a ukulele.

column1: Implementing a New Diagnostic Tool for Slack Notifications
column6:
Kaya Thomas

Notifications are an essential part of using messaging apps. If you use an app like Slack for work, not receiving notifications can have serious consequences. At Slack, we created a diagnostic tool so that users can have better context to how their notifications work. The tool checks their device settings, Slack specific settings, push token and sends a test notification if possible. With the tool we give the user actionable steps to fix anything that could potentially keep them from receiving notifications. I worked as the iOS engineer on this project and in this talk I want to explain why a diagnostic tool like this can be a game changer for apps that depend on notifications and how I implemented the tool using reactive programming. As a takeaway, the audience should have an understanding on how creating diagnostic tools can help empower their users to have better understanding of their settings as well as how to use reactive programming to cleanly implement such a tool.

Ken Ackerson

For the last year at Tumblr we have been extensively working on improving our application's start up time. Learn about many different aspects of optimizing your application's startup time as well as some interesting things we have learned along the way.

Luke Parham

If you've been working on an iOS app for a while, you may have noticed that over time your once snappy app has started to feel a little sluggish. Your feed limps along with the occasional stall or maybe you're trying to build a camera app but it seems to lag quite a bit behind reality. Contrary to popular opinion, our software is becoming increasingly demanding at a rate that easily exceeds how quickly our devices are improving. The talk explains how to track overall performance, find performance problems and how to fix a few big ones. Sprinkled throughout are 10 Rules for Good Performance.

column1: Implement Apple’s “Security at Its Core” Approach in Your Apps Across iOS, Android, Web and the Cloud
column6:
David Szabo

Apple is famous for building security into the core of every Apple product: secure auth, user device management via iCloud-hosted keychains, End-to-End Encrypted iMessage and more. But what happens when your apps run on Android, in browsers and in the cloud where you can’t take Apple’s security with you? David Szabo of Virgil Security, the company behind Twilio’s End-to-End Encrypted Messaging, will walk us through how companies like WhatsApp and Apple implemented cross-platform security and how you too can turn on these features with simple, open source building blocks to make privacy a feature and not a bug in your product. If you miss this talk, follow Virgil’s World Tour across AltConf, DeveloperWeek in NYC, Webit in Sofia, online webinars, technical workshops and more: https://virgilsecurity.com/worldtour

column1: 10 years of app marketing failures with occasional successes
column6:
Josh Michaels

As the App Store approaches the 10 year mark one topic that deserves full review is marketing. From the early days of the App Store to today the techniques for marketing apps have changed dramatically. As in all growth markets, attention became harder to get as the size of the market grew. Today techniques that worked just years ago will fail. Understanding the history of marketing in the App Store will help you avoid wasting time using old techniques that no longer work. So if you are thinking of e-mailing or tweeting at a bunch of blog writers to promote your app stop and come to this talk! In this talk, Josh will review his long string of marketing efforts in support of his independent apps. From "Ow My Balls!" to "Earthlapse" and "Magic Fireplace" Josh has experienced a wide range of successes and failures in which marketing (or the lack of it) played a crucial role. Josh will dispel a variety of myths about app marketing and featuring and provide examples of tactics NOT to use when promoting your app. For winning tactics, you'll have to find another talk. This talk is a must-attend for anyone looking to ship their own apps.
Join a few hundred of your new best friends and the AltConf team, to view the live stream of the WWDC opening Keynote!
After lunch, and before the SOTU live streams, we're bringing together the A-Team of iOS/Mac community members to discuss what was shown in the opening keynote.
We'll be live streaming the SOTU talks from WWDC
